title: Ruben Amorim responds to Wayne Rooney  naive  remark after Man Utd FA Cup exit
body_text:
Ruben Amorim stands by title claim in response to Wayne Rooneyâ€™s â€˜naiveâ€™ remark
Ruben Amorim reiterated Manchester Unitedâ€™s goal is to win the Premier League as he hit back at Wayne Rooneyâ€™s comments that he was â€œnaiveâ€ to talk about that ambition following the FA Cup fifth-round exit to Fulham.
Sunday evening brought another low in a season to forget at Old Trafford, where the side 14th in the Premier League cancelled out Calvin Basseyâ€™s opener through Bruno Fernandesâ€™ fine strike only to lose on penalties.
Bernd Leno saved Victor Lindelof and Joshua Zirkzeeâ€™s spot-kicks as the Cottagers won the shoot-out 4-3 having ended 1-1 after extra time, leaving the Europa League as Unitedâ€™s only route to silverware and continental qualification.
Amorim said â€œthe goal is to win the Premier League againâ€ in his post-match interview with the BBC, whose pundit Rooney said â€œitâ€™s a little bit naive to say â€˜Weâ€™re looking to win the Premier Leagueâ€™ because, from where they are now, theyâ€™re a long way off thatâ€.
Those comments were put to Amorim at his post-match press conference as he was asked whether it was realistic to talk about winning the title, and the United head coach said: â€œThat is the goal.
â€œBeing naive is to think that we are going to do it this season or going to be the best contender for the next season.
â€œSo, I know that in this moment everybody knows everything. I know that and itâ€™s really easy â€“ I was a pundit when I finished my career, so I know itâ€™s really easy.
Calvin Bassey was incredible at both ends of the pitch for @FulhamFC today ğŸ‘#EmiratesFACup pic.twitter.com/xWdIlwGMKm
â€” Emirates FA Cup (@EmiratesFACup) March 2, 2025
â€œOur goal is to win the Premier League. Maybe it is not with me. But our goal, as a club, the board, is winning the Premier League like we did in the past, with all the great glories and the legends of this club.
â€œWe want to do better and we know that we are in a difficult moment. And Iâ€™m not naive. Thatâ€™s why Iâ€™m here coaching at 40 years old Manchester United.â€
United co-owner Ineos has set up â€˜Mission 21â€™ to win a first Premier League crown since 2013 â€“ a 21st English league title overall â€“ with â€˜Project 150â€™ outlining the ambition to do it by the clubâ€™s 150th anniversary in 2028.
But missing out on European football would dent those hopes, with Unitedâ€™s all-time top scorer Rooney questioning how attractive a move to Old Trafford is nowadays.
â€œYou need to be in a stable position to bring the best players in,â€ Rooney said.
â€œAnd if Iâ€™m a player playing in a different country or in a different club and Manchester United come to try and sign me now, Iâ€™m looking thinking, â€˜Iâ€™m not sureâ€™.
â€œThe top players want Champions League football and unfortunately thatâ€™s not where the club are at the minute.â€
The former United star added: â€œThey were in transition when I signed but a big reason I signed was Sir Alex Ferguson because you knew heâ€™d get it right and heâ€™d build up that team again. Itâ€™s hard to see that now.â€
Just look at those faces. ğŸ¥¹ pic.twitter.com/NSDVinucVT

Unitedâ€™s attention turns to Thursdayâ€™s Europa League last-16 first leg at Real Sociedad as Fulham return to the capital buoyed by a memorable Old Trafford triumph.
It is 50 years since Fulhamâ€™s one and only FA Cup final appearance and Marco Silva was delighted by his sideâ€™s performance as they helped make amends for their quarter-final collapse at the same venue two years ago.
â€œWe wanted to play in the quarter-final and I really believe â€“ and itâ€™s my feeling â€“ that we deserve to be there,â€ the Fulham boss said after setting up a home quarter-final against Crystal Palace.
â€œFrom the first day of the competition (we thought we had an opportunity) â€“ itâ€™s not just now because we won against Man United.
â€œAnd the next one probably is going to be harder than this one. Itâ€™s going to be Palace at home but itâ€™s always the quarters-finals and you can never think that because you are home itâ€™s going to be different because itâ€™s really tough to win football matches at this level.
â€œBut we want (it) and from the first day I said â€“ and Iâ€™ve been saying â€“ that we are really serious in the competition. Itâ€™s a big competition for us.
â€œWe donâ€™t know whatâ€™s going to happen, what we are going to achieve, or where is going to be the last stage for us, but we want to think (we will exit) in the last day of the competition.
â€œIf you are going to be able and show the quality to do it, we never know but each game we are going to do in that way.

â€œThe players have been really serious. It doesnâ€™t matter against Watford or Wigan, the way we prepare ourselves and the motivation was the same in the games like it was this evening against Man United. This is the main thing for us.
â€œThe next one is against Palace at home and itâ€™s going to be really tough. Very good, difficult team to play at home because theyâ€™ve been great away from home.
â€œAt the right time we are going to prepare ourselves for that game. Now that you are in the quarters, you want to play in the semi-finals.â€
